title-group.subtitle: Its History and Use in the African American Community

abstract.p: Despite the general societal ban on use of forms of nigger, a variant finds continued acceptance among some members of the African American community for intragroup self-reference. The present research employs quantitative and qualitative analysis of data from narratives by African American comedians to show that a variant of nigger that developed in the early African American community persists in the lexicon of African American English because it conveys a social meaning that is foundational in the identity of many African Americans. Use of this form allows a speaker to construct an identity representing awareness of the history of African Americans and practical knowledge of the nature and implications of the diaspora experience. The form has been productive in its capacity to convey a range of attitudinal stances related to its basic meaning, including solidarity, censure, and a proactive stance that seeks to bring about positive change.

body.p: The Merriam-Webster Online Dictionary describes the term nigger as “perhaps the most offensive and inflammatory racial slur in English.”1 The term has been in use as a racist insult since the mid-1800s, but with increased sensitivity to the sensibilities of former targets of racial and other types of dysphemisms (Allan & Burridge 2006), it has fallen into extreme disfavor in the broader society (Henderson 2003; Allan & Burridge 2006). This is so to the extent that Henderson (2003:65) states that in the broader society, nigger is “unspeakable and has now acquired a taboo associated with the most obscene word of the English language.”

The racist form nigger is one of two contemporary forms that developed from the early use of nigger, which was at one time relatively neutral as a referential term employed by whites. The racist contemporary form consists of the same phonetic sequence as the original neutral use of nigger; since the early form nigger and the contemporary racist form are homographic, this article distinguishes between the original form and the contemporary racist form by placing the contemporary form into contexts that reveal its pejorative meaning, as in the phrase “dysphemistic use of nigger.”

The second variant of the form nigger occurs in the African American community; this variant is phonologically distinct in its ending from the form historically implemented in usages outside the African American community. Rather than taking word-final -er, the African American form ends in a schwa, without /r/, as in nigga. This ending grows out of the phonological system of African American English (AAE), which has a rule that can produce a schwa in lieu of post vocalic /r/ in an unstressed final syllable. This results in forms such as eva versus ever and teacha versus teacher (Rickford 1998; Green 2002). There are regional variations in general frequency of /r/ absence in AAE (Labov et al. 1968; Edwards 1990, 1996; Morgan 2009), but the /r/-less form nigga seems constant across regions.

Comments show that African Americans are consciously aware of the significance of the schwa ending in the AAE form nigga. A thirty-two-year-old interviewee in the present research described the -er form as “the slave form.” The comedian Eddie Griffin (2003) makes this observation: “The media tells us, ‘Why you keep sayin’ that word? ‘Nigger, nigger, nigger, nigger, nigger.’. . . You got it mixed up. We don’t say ‘nig-ger.’ We say ‘nig-ga.’ That’s two different words.” The musician and composer Quincy Jones describes the variable nigger as “a very dangerous animal. . . . All you gotta do is change the ‘a-z’ or the ‘g-a’ to a ‘g-e-r’ and we’re still right back where we started” (Jones 2006, qtd. in Echegoyen 2006).

There is an ongoing movement within the African American community to ban use of nigga. But despite efforts to erase the term from the active lexicon of African Americans, it continues to find considerable acceptance and use as a term of self-reference among African Americans. For example, the Harvard scholar Henry Louis Gates, Jr. states that he is not at all offended when nigga is used among African Americans (Gates 2009:9).

This article employs data from performances by socially conscious African American narrative comedians, as well as interviews with members of the African American community, to explore issues related to the use of nigga by African Americans. The primary question is why, since the term carries such negative historical associations, there are African Americans who accept its continued existence in the active linguistic repertoires of members of the African American community. This is a compelling question since the lexicon of AAE gives speakers access to a wide range of terms with ethnic connotations for intragroup self-reference. Terms such as brother and sister (Allen 1983; Baugh 1983, 1999; Smitherman 2000; Major 1994; Rickford & Rickford 2000) convey ethnic identity and solidarity, but without the epithetic quality historically associated with forms of nigger.

From several perspectives, this project fills a gap in research on a topic that has generated considerable public discourse. For example, the most dramatic expression of the movement to ban use of nigger occurred in July 2007, when a group of African Americans conducted a symbolic funeral for nigger, as used both in and out of the African American community (Williams 2007; Hill 2008). In another instance, a 2010 incident involving the popular psychologist Laura Schlessinger illustrates the status of nigger in the broader community: intense criticism caused Schlessinger to resign from her radio talk show after uttering “nigger” eleven times in a short segment of her show (Holden 2010).

Language in the African American community has been widely studied over the years, but the lion’s share of attention has traditionally gone to examining phonological and grammatical features (Labov et al. 1968; Wolfram 1969; Baugh 1983, 1999; Rickford 1998; Green 2002; Rickford et al. 1991). This article enters the relatively understudied area of lexicon in AAE by examining nigga and its role as a semiotically potent lexical feature that is a tool for the construction of African American identity. While there have been brief discussions of nigga in larger works (Major 1994; Spears 1998; Smitherman 2000), there have been no formal studies like this one devoted to the subject.

Exploring the traditional and emerging meanings and sociocultural associations conveyed by African American uses of the term contributes to an understanding of social identity among African Americans while adding to the store of knowledge about AAE. Since nigga is a self-selected term for naming members of the group, it is an apt subject for yielding insight into the way that at least some African Americans see themselves and their community. As well, the article contributes to the study of intraspeaker variation by showing how use of a single lexical item can contribute to the construction of personae in various attitudinal stances and illocutionary modes.

In exploring issues related to the role that nigga plays in the African American community, the article may provide insight into the ways in which other marginalized communities develop linguistic strategies to deal with labels and dysphemisms imposed on them that target characteristics such as gender, region, sexual orientation, disability, and ethnicity. The article also provides insight into responses to taboo and into issues related to appropriation and resignification.

At this point, it will be useful to discuss several terms and issues in sociolinguistics that are relevant to the development of this article. Following Coupland (2001:201), solidarity here is understood to be “analyzable as a complex of inferential processes whereby listeners reconstruct social and personal images, of and ‘through’ a speaker.” The images evoked “carry familiar or inclusive cultural echoes” and are set “against a specific backdrop of cultural experiences and assumptions” (Coupland 2001:201). This study asks whether nigga conveys unique images and social meanings that are not generally retrievable from other ethnic terms, so that if a speaker shifts from brother to nigga in a conversation, for example, it signals a shift to projection of a new aspect of African American identity. Can speakers use nigga interchangeably with other ethnic terms in similar contexts, without change of meaning? Or is the term imbued with social meaning that facilitates solidarity and construction of a specific aspect of identity? If so, how did the term acquire this social meaning?

Constructionist work on identity acknowledges that, rather than being static, social identity is dynamic, multidimensional, and multilayered (Rickford & McNair-Knox 1994; Schilling-Estes 1998; Coupland 2001, 2007). As Coupland (2007) describes, our personal identities are in many respects collages of different social category characteristics. In a given interaction, many facets of identity lie dormant, becoming active only if a specific topic or situation makes them relevant and appropriate. In these instances, speakers may deploy salient features to construct or reveal relevant aspects of identity.

Ethnic identity is a facet of social identity, but ethnic identity is itself multifaceted; not all aspects are active in a given interaction. For most African Americans, a part of ethnic identity is “transportable,” consisting of ever-present observable and distinctive characteristics (Zimmerman 1998). The salience of ethnic identity for African Americans stems from its general transportability; obstacles stemming from the visibility of African American features have led to the development and continuation of a strong group identity and solidarity.

But while a part of their identity is transportable, African Americans have agency in giving expression to other aspects of African American identity that they may choose to make a part of their presentation of self. To do this, they marshal salient resources from the array of ethnic linguistic features available to them. With varying degrees of conscious awareness and control of features, African Americans frequently employ elements of the grammatical, phonological, and lexical systems of AAE in their interactions within the African American community (Baugh 1983, 1999; Rickford & Rickford 2000; Rahman 2008). The semiotic value of features eliciting feelings of familiarity and shared cultural experiences and knowledge works to build solidarity and makes the features amenable to use in constructing identity as an African American aligned with and participating in the African American community. For some speakers, using ethnically colored terms of address and reference, including nigga, contributes to their presentation of self within the community.

Within a community, linguistic norms do not necessarily license all members to employ every linguistic feature that is current in the community. Bauman and Briggs (1990) explain that successful execution of a linguistic form requires that the speaker possess authority to use the form. Facets of identity such as age, gender, and social class may affect the legitimacy or credibility of uses by speakers who are not accorded authority by community norms to use particular features. Thus, a question regarding use of nigga is whether there are norms among the sector of the community that accepts the term that impose restrictions on who can use the term and who they may address or reference.

Beyond that, the fact that speakers select nigga from a field containing a broad array of ethnic terms raises the question of why such a plethora of ethnically tinged terms of self-reference exist in the African American lexicon in the first place. By contrast, Frankenberg (1997) notes that whites, for example, have few terms of self-reference; Allen (1983) states that whites may refer to themselves as “anglos,” “gringos,” and the like, but most ethnically rooted terms for groups of whites find use outside the named community.

The article shows that use of the form nigga continues because the term has shown that it is a linguistic resource with the capacity to convey social meaning not retrievable from other ethnically colored terms; considered alone and without regard for pejorative meanings that have historically come from outside the community, the meanings that have evolved for nigga within the African American community actually enrich the lexicon of AAE. Use of nigga is generally restricted to African American males, who typically use the term to address and refer exclusively to other males (Spears 1998; Smitherman 2000).

This article maintains that a core social meaning of nigga related to survival was part of the counterlanguage (discussed below) that early Africans in America developed. The core meaning signaled Africans in their role as survivors and participants in the diaspora experience. Members of the African slave community shared in knowledge of this core meaning, which endures in present-day uses of the term.

The fundamental survival meaning of the term nigga allows speakers to place it into contexts that give expression to a number of attitudinal stances that highlight affective aspects of identity. Stance taking, according to Du Bois (2007), involves evaluating a person, situation, or other entity and then positioning oneself in relation to that entity. The stance that a speaker takes in using nigga may result in types of negative or positive orientation that interact with the more or less salient core factor of survival meaning that remains present in uses of the term. Nigga may, for example, serve illocutionary functions related to showing approval or a proactive self-empowerment.

sec.title: Word Meaning and Taboo
sec.p: Allan and Burridge (2006) observe that taboos on language may arise as a device to forbid behaviors that are perceived as potentially harmful to a community or a segment of a community. While the seeming purpose of a slur is to insult and injure, at an unconscious level it is an effort to control the behavior of the disparaged group by imposing a negative identity on them (Allen 1983). Scholars agree that words carry with them a social history (Bauman & Briggs 1990; Ochs 1992; Coupland 2001, 2007). African Americans who reject use of nigga within the African American community are concerned that its use is symptomatic of an internalization of white racism; eradicationists see use of the term as contributing to the construction of an identity founded on self-hate (Kennedy 2002; Asim 2007).

Because nigger has historically wreaked symbolic violence (Butler 1997; Coupland 2007; Zizek 2007), often accompanied by physical violence, the negative meaning of nigger, which for some African Americans includes nigga, remains an active part of consciousness. For them, the racist meaning obliterates and disallows the legitimacy of any positive meanings that African Americans may claim for the term (Kennedy 2002; Asim 2007; Larkins 2006, qtd. in Echegoyen 2006).

But while social history endows linguistic resources with social meanings, the potential for extending or even transforming those meanings can also lie within these resources (Allen 1983; Ochs 1992; Butler 1997; Bauman & Briggs 1990; Coupland 2007; Kecskes 2008). Licensed speakers have agency to create new social meanings from existing linguistic resources. According to Allen (1983), African Americans have not accepted the stereotyping associated with the slur. Rather, they have subverted it in creative ways. And Kennedy (2002:37) asserts that “self-hatred is an implausible explanation for why many . . . progressive African Americans” continue to use the term “openly and frequently in conversations with one another.”

Because present-day uses of the form in the African American community are linked to past uses, it is useful to begin by examining the history of the term. The next section briefly outlines major points in the history of forms of nigger. After that, the discussion turns to ethnic identity labels, followed by discussion of methods involved in selecting and analyzing the data. The article then presents qualitative and quantitative analysis of use of nigga, followed by concluding remarks.

sec.title: A Brief History of the Term
sec.p: The original term nigger has undergone various processes of change over time; these are tied in with the social, economic, and cultural factors that have contributed to the development of the African American community. The historical development of the term has resulted in variants representing two major strands of meaning, consistent with oppositional meanings regarding African American identity.

Nigger appears to have entered English through borrowing of negro “black,” a word common to both Spanish and Portuguese slave traders that referenced the dark skin of Africans. The online Oxford English Dictionary (OED) cites uses of the English form as early as 1574. The dictionary describes this early usage as relatively neutral, despite the fact that the term found use within the context of the slave trade. The earliest examples provided suggest a benignly patronizing attitude that whites held toward the Africans that assumed an inferiority including less social, intellectual, and cultural development. As the online OED states, usage by whites reflected “underlying attitudes rather than a hostile use of the word itself.” For example, a 1608 entry in the OED describes the king and people of Sierra Leone as “Niggers, simple and harmless.” The mildly disparaging social meanings conveyed in early use by whites ultimately degenerated into an overt slur.

Scholars find a relationship between the societal status of a group and the likelihood that meanings of terms used to refer to members of that group will derogate (Schultz 1975; Curzan 2003). The derogation begins with shared stereotypes that allow negative social meanings to attach to a previously neutral term (McConnell-Ginet 1989; Curzan 2003). Where gender is concerned, for example, Curzan (2003:139) notes that it is widely agreed among feminist scholars that because of the lower societal position of women, “female-referential terms undergo pejoration more often that male-referential terms.”

As social, economic, and political events unfolded, nigger moved from its relatively neutral usage among whites to gain usage as an overtly hostile and abusive word meant to intimidate Africans in America and highlight their ascribed moral and intellectual inferiority. In 1837, Hosea Easton, a free African American,2 wrote of the contempt and disrespect that inhered in the negative use of the word. He described nigger as “an opprobrious term, employed to impose contempt upon blacks as an inferior race” (2007:41-42). By the mid-1800s, this overtly dysphemistic use of nigger had become “a familiar and influential insult” (Kennedy 2002:4). Allen (1990:3-4) provides an insight that helps to explain the degeneration of the term into a straightforward insult:

disp-quote.p: Ethnic slurs appear in response to social and economic conflict during historical periods of rapid social change. The coinage of most slurs may be associated with great events in our social history, particularly waves of immigration, urbanization, war and its aftermath, depressions, and massive migrations of labor.

sec.p: The pejoration of nigger into a racist dysphemism coincided with an increase in the number of free African Americans in the early nineteenth century, as well as the movement for the abolition of slavery. Writers note that both of these factors carried the potential for greater competition with whites for jobs (Milroy & Milroy 1991; Kennedy 2002; Asim 2007). An ideology developed that highlighted and intensified existing racist views; as a means of blocking African Americans from competing economically, nigger became a convenient term for indexing the subhuman characteristics being ascribed to African Americans through this ideology. Frederickson (1987:41) describes this as “an articulate and aggressive racism which excluded the Negro from the society of competing equals without deporting him, by the simple and brutal mechanism of formally defining him as subhuman.” The stereotypes and untruths related to the anti–African American ideology supported pejoration of nigger into an epithet.

The second major form, nigga, developed within the slave community. The online OED shows the nineteenth century as providing the earliest instance of use of nigga. The OED is a generally useful resource for finding the origins of English words, but assessing its value as a source showing when nigga came into use by African Americans requires consideration of the social climate that existed in America through the years leading up to the first recorded use that would have affected the availability and even accuracy of records containing speech by slaves.

Before the nineteenth century, Africans did not count as humans; without acknowledgment of the humanity of the slaves, there was little interest in recording or publishing their speech, so that the first use cited by OED does not necessarily reflect the beginning of use in the African American community. The OED’s earliest record may reflect the fact that the abolitionist movement, the Civil War, and other events of the nineteenth century created a climate where there was a greater interest in exploring the lives of African Americans.

Beyond that, if there were records containing the writing or speech of slaves before the first instance of nigga reported by OED, it is not certain that writers would have accurately captured its phonological characteristics. With the extensive media discourse that currently surrounds nigga, contemporary writers are aware of its salience, but without the knowledge and sensitivities of contemporary writers, transcribers in the past may have produced an eye dialect that targeted certain features perceived as characteristic of African American speech, while neglecting others, including the schwa ending in nigga. Ex-slave narratives, for example, record the perceptions of a transcriber, but do not necessarily convey accurate representations of the features of African American language. In the present research, Richard Pryor produces nigga to the exclusion of nigger, yet a concert title drawn from one of his concert lines appears as “That Nigger’s Crazy.”

Scholars believe that a nonpejorative variant of nigger entered the lexicon of African Americans early on (Dillard 1977; Spears 1998); according to Spears (1998:240), the term was probably in use among Africans in America in “the earliest days of Anglophone America.” It is impossible to know exactly when a form of nigger entered the lexicon of African Americans, but certain known circumstances surrounding the experiences of the slaves from their arrival in America in the seventeenth century lend themselves to a likely explanation.

Based on documented conditions of their existence, it is reasonable to believe that the slaves began to use a variant of nigger shortly after their arrival, as they learned English. Records from at least 1715 show that immediately on arrival in the western hemisphere, slaves generally began a one- to three-year period of “seasoning,” where they adjusted to their new environment and status in life (Gaspar 1992; Gomez 1998). The historian Michael Gomez (1998:14) offers that “learning the rudiments of a European language was part of the (seasoning) process.” For slaves here in America, this meant learning some English “as a necessary prerequisite to performing tasks” and “allowing for communication between slaveholder (or overseer) and slave” (Gomez 1998:173).

Scholars generally agree that slaves were usually separated from their countrymen on arrival in America (Higgins 1976). The Africans were second language learners with fluent command of their native languages, but who, because of the commonality of their plight, felt a compelling “need to communicate with Africans of dissimilar background” (Gomez 1998:172). In that vein, they were in need of a commonly understood term of self-reference for members of the group of slaves.

Gomez asserts that slaveholders and overseers consistently described slaves with modifiers indicating their relative degree of seasoning. These included, for example, “salt-water” for newly imported slaves and “country-born” for slaves born in America. According to Gomez, nigger was the one term the slaves heard used with these modifiers (Gomez 1998). Because it was a commonly heard term in the language they were learning, nigger was a convenient and logical label for the slaves to employ to refer to themselves. Early uses of variants of nigger in the slave and dominant communities carried similar referential meanings; the term referred to an African. But as Coupland (2007:20) points out, “forms can express what is referentially the same meaning while different social nuances are present.” The social meanings for nigger that developed among members of the African diaspora in America were distinctive to that group. The pronunciation, as well, differed for the slaves.

The variant that developed among the slaves took an open syllable ending, as is common in West African languages (Bhambose 1969; Dakubu 1988). As mentioned above, the Africans who came to America had the task of learning English as a second language; in second language learning, features of a native language may carry over into pronunciation of words in the new language (Skehan 1998). Where a learner’s native language lacks a feature that occurs in the target language, the learner may make adjustments based on the phonological system of her or his native language. This happens, for example, when native speakers of German retain devoicing of final voiced consonants when learning English; a German speaking English as a second language may produce blk for big.

West African languages such as Fula, Wolof, and Yoruba are, in many ways, structurally similar to each other (Bhambose 1969; Dakubu 1988). They rarely have word-final unstressed syllables consisting of a midcentral vowel and /r/, as in nigger. Frequently, though, West African words end with open syllables (Bhambose 1969; Dakubu 1988; Abibatu Bah personal communication January 7, 2001; Kumba Fall personal communication January 21, 2011). Since it does not occur in their language, for speakers of West African languages, a final syllable consisting of an unstressed midcentral vowel followed by /r/ can lead to interference in producing English; speakers of Yoruba, for example, lose /r/ in a word such as doctor, to produce a form having a final open syllable (Bangbose 1969). Under this view, the open syllable ending in present day forms such as eva “ever,” fatha “father,” and nigga has roots in West African languages.

Linguists have written of the association between West African languages and contemporary AAE (Singler 1993; Rickford 1998; Winford 1998), but the question of retention of African features in AAE is a complex one, complicated by factors related to issues such as the operation of the slavery system and to pidginization and creolization. And there does not appear to be in existence a model for probable consonant, vowel, and syllable systems for West African languages or a proto–West African language of two to four centuries ago. Still, the similarity in phonological endings for contemporary West African languages suggests a historic commonality (Bynon 1977; Crowley 1997), so that West African languages of the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries that the slaves spoke had similar phonologies. There is need for further research in this area, but where a form of nigger is concerned, it is reasonable that English served as a lexifier, providing a commonly understood term of self-reference, and that the slaves produced a variant ending in an open syllable.

A continued desire to “maintain distance, distinctiveness, and some sense of ownership” (Gomez 1998:177) is among the social factors that contributed to the retention of the open syllable ending and other African features in the language of the slaves. Linguistic features become resources imbued with social meaning through repeated use in contexts that community members are aware of and understand (Bauman & Briggs 1990; Coupland 2001). This article posits that in the counterlanguage, discussed below, social meanings developed among the Africans that reflected a view in which they saw themselves as survivors and as humans whose freedom and dignity had been assaulted. Historic records of mutinies such as those involving the slaveships Henry and Amistad show that while Africans saw themselves as what Zizek (2007) refers to as “inferiorized,” or placed into a subordinate position, they did not develop an identity as inferior beings. Insurrections such as the New York City Slave Revolt in 1712 and those of Denmark Vesey and Nat Turner show this as well. Autobiographical narratives such as that of Olaudah Equiano (Pine 1999) also display dignity and a will to survive.

As in determining exactly when nigga entered the lexicon of the slaves, it is impossible to locate the moment when nigga developed social meanings related to survival. Still, there is evidence that this meaning existed during the time of slavery. Works show that African Americans were using the term with survival meaning since at least the early 1800s (Stuckey 1994; Jacobs 2001; Wilson 2002). The following excerpt from a field holler that slave children sang, for example, emphasizes slaves as survivors. The song warns runaway slaves that patrollers are nearby (Stuckey 1994:10). The transcription targets certain perceived features of the language of African Americans, while overlooking others, including the -a ending in nigga.

sec.p: Historically, Africans in America employed their survival strategies within the context of an antisociety. Goffman (1961) and Halliday (1978) maintain that antisocieties often form in situations where subjugated people covertly resist domination. Morgan (2002:23) presents the view that antisocieties “typically emerge when those who dominate individuals require that the subjugated display an attitude that reaffirms the dominator/dominated relationship—in the presence of others—by verbal or physical confirmation (e.g. bowing heads . . .).” An antisociety can give rise to a system of communication, a counterlanguage, that serves the functions of everyday speech. With constant awareness that their words could reach the ears of enemies, the slaves fashioned their counterlanguage with English words and phrases that could have complex, multilayered, and often seemingly contradictory meanings that were decipherable only to insiders (Morgan 2002:23). The inaccessibility that slaveholders had to the survival meaning made nigga a useful tool in the counterlanguage that developed within the context of the slave antisociety.

Use of a code that highlights indirectness to avoid detection is not unique to early African Americans. The gay community, for example, has developed ways to privately signal gay identity in the presence of outsiders. Since gay identity is not necessarily transportable, the coded messages that members of the community send may allow their gay identity to remain unnoticed so they can avoid potential harm and harassment from biased outsiders who may be listening (Leap 1996; Liang 1999). Queen (1998:209) states, for instance, that the question “Are you family?” is often used to covertly ask, “Are you gay?”

Among slaves, the counterlanguage served two primary functions. While purposeful linguistic ambiguity could not necessarily shield intragroup communication from spies who might be among them, it did serve the pragmatic function of providing some protection for their conversations and plans from the slave masters. The counterlanguage also provided a means for slaves to project a social face (Goffman 1961; Morgan 2002) that challenged and resisted the unjust domination that required them to “have the ‘attitude’ of someone who should be oppressed” (Morgan 2002:25). For example, through the counterlanguage, slaves were known to have covertly mimicked and ridiculed the slave master in his presence (Cowan 2001).

Within the antisociety, Africans developed an identity as pragmatic and resourceful survivors who had been displaced into an unjust situation where, as Kolchin (1993:154) asserts, “surviving in a heartless world assumes overriding importance.” During the period of slavery, nigga became a term that Africans used to refer to themselves and companions in the struggle to survive. Using the term highlighted the identity of a speaker as participating in the culture of survival.

“Speakers are linked by a historical chain of discourse to those whom they hear and those to whom they speak” (Hill 2008:57). Roots of present-day uses of the term in the African American community lie in the counterlanguage, where the term served as a symbol representing the most salient aspect of slaves’ identity. This meaning exists to this day for African Americans who are not focused on the racist use of the term, but use nigga as a tool to project a facet of identity as a culturally aware survivor in the diaspora. Nigga conveys meanings related to this facet of identity in a way that other, more recent ethnic terms of self-reference cannot.

sec.title: Ethnic Identity Labels and Identity
sec.p: In the lexicon of AAE, nigga exists in a field containing a number of terms that allow African Americans to address or refer specifically to other African Americans. Since these terms generally provide ways of expressing African American identity and solidarity with the community, the comedians in this research have access to a range of options for using ethnonyms and other ethnically colored terms to aid in establishing solidarity and rapport with their audiences. While all these terms refer to African Americans, each term carries defining connotations and collocation rules that distinguish it from other entries in the field of ethnically laden terms of address and reference. The words interrelate and contribute to defining each other, so that selecting nigga from the field entails highlighting particular characteristics that this term carries in ways that others cannot. Table 1 shows terms conveying ethnic meaning that appear in the comedic data, along with the number of their occurrences. Terms such as playa, baby, and dog appear infrequently and are included in the “Other” category.

sec.p: While all of the terms in the table highlight ethnic identity and solidarity, nigga is far and away the most frequently used term, constituting 70 percent of total occurrences of terms. There are several related reasons why this might be so. Restrictions related to factors such as grammar, gender, collocation, and nuanced social meanings may proscribe the use of other terms in situations where the comedians use nigga. Terms that speakers use for addressing and referencing are selected from similar repertoires (Coupland 2007:55). But the present research shows that unlike some ethnic terms in the data, nigga can serve functions of both addressing and referencing.

The term boy has strict grammatical and collocational restrictions that nigga does not have. It is generally insulting to address an African American adult male as “boy” (Burton 1995; Hughes 1998; Smitherman 2000). Boy used in third person referring to a man is insulting, but preceded by a possessive it conveys a meaning of camaraderie and solidarity.

An illustration of boundaries for use of boy is in the reaction of interviewees to a comment by A. J. Johnson. Establishing a close bond with the hip-hop artist Master P had been very helpful to Johnson in advancing his career. Expressing an attitudinal stance of gratitude, respect, and close friendship, Johnson says, “I hooked up with Master P. That’s my nigga.” Interviewees agree that “nigga” here suggests a close relationship where Master P is “something like a brother” who has helped Johnson to survive through difficult times. When asked whether using “boy” rather than “nigga” would have affected the meaning of Johnson’s utterance, one interviewee said that using “boy” would have yielded a similar meaning, but “without the closeness” implied by use of “nigga.” As the thirty-two-year-old said,
